I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During  the  country  programming  mission  in  2010,  the  Government  of  the  People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) requested capacity development technical assistance (TA) for carbon 
market development in Tianjin.1 It was agreed with the Tianjin municipal government (TMG) and 
the Ministry of Finance that the scope of the TA would be to develop the pilot Tianjin emission 
trading system (TETS) and the associated market infrastructure. Based on this understanding, 
the name of the TA was changed to Developing Tianjin Emission Trading System and the 
concept paper for the TA was approved on 21 October 2011.2 
 
2.  During the TA fact-finding, an agreement was reached on the overall design, impact, 
outcome, and outputs of the TA; and the outline terms of reference for consultants, including the 
implementation  arrangements,  cost  details,  and financing  plan. The design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  During the Eleventh Five-Year Plan, 2006–2010, the PRC achieved a reduction of about 
19.1% in the energy intensity of its economy.3 Since it relies heavily on coal, the energy intensity 
reduction in the PRC proportionately reduced carbon emissions. The energy intensity reduction 
recorded in the eleventh plan was accompanied by an increase in the share of non-fossil fuel 
sources of energy (i.e., renewable and nuclear) and low-carbon fossil fuel (i.e., natural gas). 
This energy intensity reduction was achieved primarily through a set of administrative measures 
that included (i) targeted energy efficiency improvement in the country’s largest energy-intensive 
industries, (ii) incentives for energy efficiency improvements for bulk users, and (iii) phasing out 
of obsolete and inefficient industrial capacity.  
 
4.  The PRC has committed to reduce its carbon intensity by 40%–45% in 2020 compared 
with 2005 and to increase the share of non-fossil fuel in the primary energy supply to 15% by 
2020. 4 In line with this, the Twelfth Five-Year Plan, 2011–2015 has set targets for reduction in 
energy intensity (16%) and carbon intensity (17%) by 2015 compared with 2010 and to increase 
the non-fossil contribution in primary energy supply to 11.8% by 2015 compared with 8.6% in 
2010. In addition, the twelfth plan set specific targets to improve the urban air quality through 
emission reduction as the urban areas of the PRC are suffering from poor air quality.  
 
5.  While administrative measures achieved substantial energy efficiency savings during the 
eleventh plan, these measures need to be complemented by more market-oriented approaches 
to provide economic incentives for emission reduction. One such approach is to enable the 
trading of emission reductions between enterprises that have obligations for emission reduction. 
This would provide incentives for emission reduction to be achieved in economic sectors that 
have the least cost for emission reduction. The government has proposed to pilot test cap-and-
trade of carbon dioxide emissions in selected industry sectors and regions during the twelfth 
plan by establishing provincial emission trading systems (ETSs). The carbon dioxide trading can 
also provide co-benefits such as reduction in local pollutants. This would improve the urban air

6.  The emission trading markets have evolved since 2005 in many developed countries 
with mixed results. The evolving emission trading markets can be broadly classified into cap-
and-trade5 and  baseline  and  credit  markets.6 Both  of  these  market  structures  transform 
emission savings into a tradable commodity. When the market participants voluntarily set a cap 
on their emissions, it is referred to as a voluntary cap-and-trade market, and when a regulator 
sets a cap on emission from certain economic sectors, it is referred to as a mandatory cap-and-
trade market. A cap-and-trade-based market is usually referred to as ETS; the European ETS is 
the best known mandatory cap-and-trade market.  
 
7.  The  baseline  and  credit  and  cap-and-trade  markets  can  be  linked  through  offset 
mechanisms. In offsetting, credits generated through baseline and credit markets, in economic 
sectors or regions not covered in the cap-and-trade market, are used to offset emissions within 
the capped regions. The cap-and-trade market regulators usually stipulate the type and quantity 
of offsets that can be used in lieu of emission allowances. The European ETS (i.e., cap-and-
trade  market)  accepts  the  certified  emission  reductions  under  the  Clean  Development 
Mechanism (i.e., baseline and credit market) as an offset subject to certain limitations.  
 
8.  Given  the  complexities  and  potential  economic  impacts  of  emission  trading,  the 
government has decided to pilot test cap-and-trade-based emission trading at the provincial 
level. This would enable useful lessons to be learned on the challenges of designing a national 
ETS in a rapidly growing developing economy, as international experience, with respect to 
emission trading, is limited to more mature moderately growing economies.  
 
9.  Tianjin had been designated a low-carbon city by the government, and has been invited 
by the National Development and Reform Commission to submit proposals for establishing a 
pilot ETS (other cities and provinces that were identified for pilot testing ETS are Beijing and 
Shanghai, Chongqing municipalities, Guangdong and Hubei provinces). TMG has approved the 
overall plan for establishing the Tianjin emission trading market and formally submitted the 
proposal to establish a pilot cap-and-trade-based TETS in August 2011. It was proposed that 
the (i) feasibility study for emission trading would be approved by the National Development and 
Reform Commission before the end of 2011, (ii) pre-conditions for emission trading would be 
established by the end of 2012, and (iii) TETS would commence operations in 2013. This would 
enable the government authorities to gather useful lessons from the TETS to be incorporated in 
the national ETS, which is expected to be established in 2015. 
 
10.  As a first step toward establishing a carbon market in Tianjin, TMG, in collaboration with 
Petro China, established the Tianjin Climate Exchange (TCX) in 2008. TCX has undertaken 
                                                
5  A cap-and-trade market is created when the market participants within a certain jurisdiction receive an overall cap 
on the emissions they can emit over the trading period. The individual market participants receive an emission 
allowance that would contribute to the overall cap on emissions. The market participants need to match their actual 
emissions with the emission allowances possessed by them at the end of trading period. The cap-and-trade market 
enables the market participants to trade the emission allowances among each other if the actual emissions exceed 
or fall short of their allowance. 
6 In the baseline and credit markets, the carbon credits are defined as the difference in emissions between 
emissions after mitigations measures in comparison to the baseline (i.e., the emissions trajectory under the 
business-as-usual scenario). Well-defined standards and methodologies are required for quantifying the emission 
reduction from mitigation measures and institutional arrangements for measuring, validating, and issuing emission 
reductions  in  baseline  and  credit  markets.  The  Clean  Development  Mechanism  under  the  United  Nations 
Framework Convention on Climate Change is the most well-known example of baseline and credit market.

3 
several  pioneering  initiatives  and  research  studies  on  carbon  markets.  These  include 
(i) structuring carbon neutrality products, (ii) attempting to establish a voluntary emission trading 
mechanism  among  several  industrial  establishments,  (iii)  establishing  an  electronic  trading 
platform for major pollutants (sulfur dioxide), and (iv) conceptualizing the reduction of energy 
intensity in civil building sector using market-based approaches.  
 
11.  TMG, in consultation with the government, will have to decide several key strategic 
issues prior to establishing the TETS. These include the following:  
(i)  Whether the emission trading system would be based on intensity-based 
targets or absolute targets? Although the intensity-based target is consistent 
with the stated pledge of the PRC for emission reduction, the monitoring and 
verification requirements are more complex for intensity-based ETS. 
(ii)  How  the  emission  trading  system  interacts  with  other  administrative 
policies  aimed  at  reducing  carbon  and  energy  intensity?  These  include 
energy  conservation  performance targets for key  enterprises,  phasing  out  of 
obsolete  technologies  and  industrial  capacities,  and  fiscal  incentives  and 
penalties for inefficient industries. The ETS should be designed to complement 
these policies. 
(iii)  Sector scope of the emission trading system. The economic sectors to be 
included in the ETS need to be decided based on the (a) likely economic impact 
of emission caps on the sector, including competitiveness; (b) ability of the sector 
to  reduce  emissions  through  technological  innovation;  (c)  contribution  of  the 
sector to the overall emissions in the province; (d) feasibility of implementing 
measurements and verification of emissions of the sector; and (e) readiness of 
sector entities to participate in the ETS. 
(iv)  Determination of the emission target. The amount of emission reduction to be 
achieved and the cost of compliance for the participants need to be examined. A 
stringent target would have more severe economic implications, including carbon 
leakage to provinces with less stringent emission requirements. 
(v)  Price control mechanisms. It is necessary to decide whether to allow flexible 
caps or other forms of safety valves, such as additional emission allowances, if 
the market price exceeds a predefined level.  
(vi)  Allocation methodology of allowances. The emission allocation methodology 
needs to be determined at the outset. Free allocation wins the support of market 
participants,  but  it  may  result  in  windfall  profits,  while  the  auctioning  of 
allowances would provide a more market-oriented allocation of allowances.  
(vii)  Offsets and linkages with other markets, including voluntary markets. The 
offsets provide an avenue to link the proposed ETS with the voluntary market for 
domestically issued verified emission reduction. The linkages with other ETS in 
the PRC would enable emission allowances to be traded across several ETSs 
and therefore increase the market liquidity. The types and amount of offsets to be 
allowed need to be determined as part of the design of the TETS.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
12.  The impact will be the establishment of a national cap-and-trade-based ETS in the PRC 
to contribute to emission reduction. The national ETS is expected to provide adequate market-
based price signals for emission reduction and play a key role in reducing the carbon intensity of 
the PRC’s economy. The outcome will be successfully pilot testing the TETS to provide useful

4   
lessons for the establishment of a national ETS. The TETS will also provide market-based 
incentives for emission reduction to enterprises from economic sectors covered in the TETS.  
   
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
13.  The TA is expected to deliver the following outputs.  
 
14.  Output 1: Provide strategic policy advice on the overall design of the Tianjin 
emission trading system. The TA consultants will undertake an analytical study of the key 
policy and strategic issues pertaining to the design of an ETS, such as: (i) identifying the key 
criteria for the different economic sectors to be included in the ETS, (ii) setting the level of 
emission  cap  for  the  economic  sectors  included  in  the  ETS,  and  (iii)  examining  how  the 
emission allowances should be allocated to market participant. The TA consultants will take into 
account the experience and lessons from ETSs established in other parts of the world. The TA 
consultants will also undertake econometric modeling to ascertain the economic impacts of the 
introduction of ETS and to estimate the financial impacts on market participants.  
 
15.  Output  2:  Prepare  detailed  design  of  the  Tianjin  emission  trading  system, 
including the trading rules and regulatory systems. Upon finalization of the broad design 
parameters of the TETS by the policy makers, the TA consultants will undertake detailed design 
of the ETS, including trading rules such as eligibility of offsets, price control mechanism and 
monitoring, and verification protocols for settlement of emission allowances. This will include 
recommendations on institutional and legal frameworks for market regulation.  
 
16.  Output 3: Commission the trading platform and registry for the Tianjin emission 
trading system. The consultant will prepare detailed technical specifications for the trading 
platform and registry, for recording the property rights of emission allowances held by market 
participants. Based on the specifications prepared, the TA consultants will assist the TCX in 
procuring and developing the hardware and software systems required for the trading platform 
and registry from third parties and software vendors.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000 equivalent,7 of which (i) $200,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB’s) Technical Assistance Special Fund 
(TASF—other sources) and (ii) $550,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the Climate 
Change Fund.8 TMG, through the implementing agency, will provide in-kind contribution in the 
form of office accommodation, logistic facilities, and remuneration of counterpart staff. The 
detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  Tianjin  Finance  Bureau  will  be  the  executing  agency  for  the  TA.  TCX  will  be  the 
implementing agency. The TA will commence on 15 March 2012 and will be completed on 
31 December 2013. The TA consultants will work under the guidance of the leading group 
appointed by TMG to establish the TETS under the leadership of Tianjin Development and 
Reform Commission. The TA will be carried out by a team of international (6 person-months) 
and national consultants (18 person-months) having extensive knowledge and expertise in

(i) energy  economics  and  industrial  policy,  especially  policies  pertaining  to  low-carbon 
development in the PRC; (ii) the design and regulation of ETSs in other parts of the world; and 
(iii) developing technical specifications for emission trading platforms and emission allowance 
registries. The outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. The consultants 
will be engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time) using the quality- and cost-based selection method (with a quality–
cost ratio of 80:20). The consulting firm will be required to submit a simplified technical proposal 
covering all aspects of the terms of reference.  
 
19.  All procurement will be carried out using the shopping method in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time) by the implementing agency. All 
equipment, including the software and hardware systems purchased under the TA, will be 
turned over to the implementing agency after TA completion. A software design company for the 
development of the trading platform and registry, based on the technical specification prepared 
by the consulting firm, will be recruited through fixed budget selection by ADB as (i) the detailed 
technical  specification  for  the  software  system  and  the  inputs  required  would  have  been 
finalized by the TA consultants (para. 18), and (ii) the budget is fixed and cannot be exceeded. 
The  selection  criteria  will  include  the  ability  to  provide  continuing  service  for  software 
maintenance and upgrades beyond the time frame covered in the initial contract and local 
presence  in  the  PRC.  The  proceeds  of  the  TA  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  the 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time.)  
 
20.  Tripartite meetings among ADB, the executing and implementing agencies, and the 
consultants  will  be  held  at  the  commencement  and  conclusion  of  each  output  to  provide 
guidance  to  the  consultants  and  to  review  their  reports. Workshops  and  seminars  will  be 
conducted to collect comments on consultants’ reports and disseminate the main findings of the 
TA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Developing Tianjin Emission Trading 
System, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

3.  This task  will  be  undertaken  by  an  energy  and  climate  policy  expert  (international, 
1.5 person-months),  climate  policy  expert  (national,  2  person-months),  and  econometrician 
(national, 2 person-months). The detailed tasks under this output include the following: 
(i)  Providing in-depth review of existing and planned ETSs in Australia, Canada, 
Europe, Japan, New Zealand, and the United States. Based on this, draw useful 
lessons relevant to the design of Tianjin ETS (TETS), taking into account the 
specific circumstances of the PRC and Tianjin. 
(ii)  Reviewing ongoing progress and system choices made, related to ETSs (policy 
and practices), including but not limited to the six ETS pilot provinces and cities 
of Beijing, Chongqing, Guangdong, Hubei, Shanghai, and Tianjin, as well as the 
guidelines provided by the Government of the PRC for establishing pilot ETSs. 
(iii)  Reviewing the energy and climate policies and targets under the Twelfth Five-
Year Plan, 2011–2015 and other related policies in Tianjin, analyze the impact of 
emission trading on existing policies, and estimate the cost of compliance with 
emission reduction targets with and without emission trading for key economic 
sectors.  
(iv)  Analyzing these existing or planned climate and energy policies at national and 
subnational levels regarding their likely interactions with ETSs. 
(v)  Preparing a policy paper addressing the following issues: 
(a)  How to translate the intensity-based emission targets of the PRC to an 
absolute emission cap for the purpose of trading? 
(b)  How  emission  trading  systems  interact  with  other  administrative 
policies  aimed  at  reducing  carbon  and  energy  intensity?  These 
include  energy  conservation  performance  targets  for  key  enterprises, 
phasing out of obsolete technologies and industrial capacities, and fiscal 
incentives  and  penalties for  inefficient  industries. The  ETS  should  be 
designed to complement these policies. 
(c)  Sector scope of the emission trading system. The economic sectors 
to be included in the ETS need to be decided based on the (i) likely

for the participants. A more stringent target would also have more severe 
economic implications, including carbon leakage to provinces with less 
stringent emission requirements. 
(vi)  Undertaking econometric modeling to assess the likely economic impact of the 
proposed ETS on economic sectors to be covered in the ETS. Based on the 
modeling, it will undertake the following: 
(a)  Propose the emission caps to be set and the likely emission allowance 
prices. 
(b)  Given  the  announced  national  and  regional  targets,  analyze  the 
stringency of the targets in terms of abatement cost for different sectors 
and regions that might be covered by the ETS.   
(c)  Identify  key  challenges  and  opportunities  and  analyze  the  risks  and 
effects of carbon leakage. 
 
2.  Output 2: Prepare Detailed Design of the Tianjin Emission Trading System, 
including the Trading Rules and Regulatory Systems 
 
4.  This task will be undertaken by an ETS expert (international, 2.5 person-months), carbon 
market expert (national, 4 person-months), and market regulation expert (national, 4 person-
months). The detailed tasks under this output include: 
(i)  Undertaking structured consultations with the market participants to obtain their 
views on the design aspects of the TETS. 
(ii)  Proposing the necessary legal and policy framework, including draft decrees, to 
enable the establishment of TETS. 
(iii)  Proposing institutional arrangements for market regulation, taking into account 
the existing arrangements for financial market regulation in Tianjin. 
(iv)  Proposing procedures for issuing emission allowances to the participants of the 
ETS and managing the allocation of emission allowances to market participants. 
(v)  Proposing the monitoring and verification procedures and protocols for the ETS 
system  and  making  recommendation  for  capacity  building  of  third-party 
verification agencies.  
(vi)  Making recommendations on whether to allow flexible caps or other forms of 
safety  valves,  such  as  additional  emission  allowances,  if  the  market  price 
exceeds a predefined level.  
(vii)  Making recommendations regarding the length of the trading period, taking into 
account the time frames for pilot testing of the TETS. 
(viii)  Making recommendations regarding the allocation methodology of allowances.1  
(ix)  Making recommendations regarding the eligibility of offsets and linkages with 
other markets, including voluntary markets. The offsets provide an avenue to link 
the proposed ETS with the voluntary market for domestically issued voluntary 
                                                
1  While free allocation wins the support of market participants, it may result in windfall profits, while auctioning of 
allowances would provide more market-oriented allocation of allowances.

Appendix 3  11 
emission  reductions.  Linkages  with  other  ETSs  in  the  PRC  would  enable 
emission allowances to be traded across several ETSs and increase the market 
liquidity. 
(x)  Proposing how the property rights for emission allowances would be recorded 
and how they would be retired at the end of the trading period. 
(xi)  Undertaking information dissemination.  
 
3.  Output 3: Commission the Trading Platform and Registry for the Tianjin 
Emission Trading System 
 
5.  This task will be undertaken by a trading platform design ETS expert (international, 
2 person-months), and three national consultants for 2 person-months each (trading system 
framework designer, trading system risk control specialist, and system integration expert). This 
component also includes the development of the trading platform and registry by an information 
technology vendor in accordance with the technical specifications prepared by the consultants. 
The detailed tasks under this output include the following: 
(i)  Preparing  the  technical  specifications  for  the  trading  platform  for  the  Tianjin 
Climate Exchange (TCX) to act as the primary exchange for the proposed TETS 
as well as for other ETSs to be established in the PRC. 
(ii)  Preparing the technical specifications for the registry to record the property rights 
of emission allowances acquired by market participants through initial allocation 
or trading. The registry should also be capable of recording the eligible offsets 
acquired by the market participants and should incorporate an appropriate level 
of security arrangements.  
(iii)  Assisting TCX in recruiting a competent software vendor to develop the trading 
platform based on the specifications prepared. 
(iv)  Making recommendations regarding the information technology hardware and 
off-the-shelf software packages to be used in developing the trading platform and 
market registry. 
(v)  Supervising the development of the trading platform and registry by the software 
vendor and providing feedback as appropriate during the development phase. 
(vi)  Undertaking the commissioning tests and acceptance of the trading platform and 
registry. 
(vii)  Providing capacity building to the staff of the TCX and other market participants 
regarding the operation of the trading system. 
 
B.  Reporting Requirements 
6.  The  consultants  will  submit  an  inception  report  within  1  month  after  signing  the 
consulting  contract.  The  interim  reports,  for  each  output,  will  be  provided  3  months  after 
commencement of the task, and the draft final reports upon completion of each output. The 
consultants will take into account the comments provided by the Asian Development Bank and 
the implementing agency on the draft final report for each output and the consolidated final 
report will be submitted upon completion of the final report. All reports will be provided in English 
and in Chinese language.
